member.name: T:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable
member.summary: Provides a set of static methods for querying objects that implement .

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Acquire``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Ensures that a source sequence of objects are all acquired successfully. If the acquisition of any one fails then those successfully acquired till that point are disposed.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in sequence.
member.param: Source sequence of objects.
member.returns: Returns an array of all the acquired objects in source order.
member.remarks: This operator executes immediately.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.AggregateRight``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,``0,``0})
member.summary: Applies a right-associative accumulator function over a sequence. This operator is the right-associative version of the LINQ operator.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of source.
member.param: Source sequence.
A right-associative accumulator function to be invoked on each element.
member.returns: The final accumulator value.
member.example:
string result = Enumerable.Range(1, 5).Select(i => i.ToString()).AggregateRight((a, b) => string.Format("({0}/{1})", a, b));
The result variable will contain "(1/(2/(3/(4/5))))".
member.remarks: This operator executes immediately.

member.summary: Returns the Cartesian product of two sequences by enumerating all possible combinations of one item from each sequence, and applying a user-defined projection to the items in a given combination.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of .
The type of the elements of .
The type of the elements of the result sequence.
member.param: The first sequence of elements.
The second sequence of elements.
A projection function that combines elements from all of the sequences.
member.returns: A sequence of elements returned by .

remarks.para: The method returns items in the same order as a nested foreach loop, but all sequences except for are cached when iterated over. The cache is then re-used for any subsequent iterations.
This method uses deferred execution and stream its results.

The function used to determine if an element in the sequence is considered missing.

members.member:
Returns a sequence with each missing element in the source replaced with the following non-missing element in that sequence. Additional parameters specifiy two functions, one used to determine if an element is considered missing or not and another to provide the replacement for the missing element.
The source sequence. The function used to determine if an element in the sequence is considered missing. The function used to produce the element that will replace the missing one. Its first argument receives the current element considered missing while the second argument receives the next non-missing element. Type of the elements in the source sequence. An with missing values replaced.
An with missing elements filled.
This method uses deferred execution semantics and streams its results. If elements are missing at the end of the sequence then they remain missing.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Flatten(System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Flattens a sequence containing arbitrarily-nested sequences.
member.param: The sequence that will be flattened.
member.returns: A sequence that contains the elements of and all nested sequences (except strings).

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Flatten(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Func{System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Flattens a sequence containing arbitrarily-nested sequences. An additional parameter specifies a predicate function used to determine whether a nested should be flattened or not.
member.param: The sequence that will be flattened.
A function that receives each element that implements and indicates if its elements should be recursively flattened into the resulting sequence.
member.returns: A sequence that contains the elements of and all nested sequences for which the predicate function returned true.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Flatten(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Func{System.Object,System.Collections.IEnumerable})
member.summary: Flattens a sequence containing arbitrarily-nested sequences. An additional parameter specifies a function that projects an inner sequence via a property of an object.
member.param: The sequence that will be flattened.

A function that receives each element of the sequence as an object and projects an inner sequence to be flattened. If the function returns null then the object argument is considered a leaf of the flattening process.
member.returns: A sequence that contains the elements of and all nested sequences projected via the function.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.FullGroupJoin``3(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``1},System.Func{``0,``2},System.Func{``1,``2})
member.summary: Performs a Full Group Join between the and sequences.
member.remarks: This operator uses deferred execution and streams the results. The results are yielded in the order of the elements found in the first sequence followed by those found only in the second. In addition, the callback responsible for projecting the results is supplied with sequences which preserve their source order.

The type of the elements in the second input sequence
The type of the key to use to join
member.param: First sequence
Second sequence
The mapping from first sequence to key
The mapping from second sequence to key
member.returns: A sequence of elements joined from and .

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Generate``1(``0,System.Func{``0,``0})
member.summary: Returns a sequence of values consecutively generated by a generator function.
member.typeparam: Type of elements to generate.
member.param: Value of first element in sequence
Generator function which takes the previous series element and uses it to generate the next element.
member.returns: A sequence containing the generated values.
member.remarks: This function defers element generation until needed and streams the results.
member.example:
var result = MoreEnumerable.Generate(2, n => n * n).Take(5);
The result variable, when iterated over, will yield 2, 4, 16, 256, and 65536, in turn.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.GenerateByIndex``1(System.Func{System.Int32,``0})
member.summary: Returns a sequence of values based on indexes.
member.typeparam: The type of the value returned by and therefore the elements of the generated sequence.
member.param: Generation function to apply to each index.
member.returns: A sequence of generated results.

remarks.para: The sequence is (practically) infinite where the index ranges from zero to inclusive.
This function defers execution and streams the results.

member.remarks: This method is implemented by using deferred execution and streams the groupings. The grouping elements, however, are buffered. Each grouping is therefore yielded as soon as it is complete and before the next grouping occurs.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Interleave``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0}[])
member.summary: Interleaves the elements of two or more sequences into a single sequence, skipping sequences as they are consumed
member.remarks:
Interleave combines sequences by visiting each in turn, and returning the first element of each, followed by the second, then the third, and so on. So, for example:
{1,1,1}.Interleave( {2,2,2}, {3,3,3} ) => { 1,2,3,1,2,3,1,2,3 }
This operator behaves in a deferred and streaming manner.
When sequences are of unequal length, this method will skip those sequences that have been fully consumed and continue interleaving the remaining sequences.
The sequences are interleaved in the order that they appear in the collection, with as the first sequence.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of the source sequences
member.param: The first sequence in the interleave group
The other sequences in the interleave group
member.returns: A sequence of interleaved elements from all of the source sequences

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Interleave``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.ImbalancedInterleaveStrategy,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0}[])
member.summary: Interleaves the elements of two or more sequences into a single sequence, applying the specified strategy when sequences are of unequal length
member.remarks:
Interleave combines sequences by visiting each in turn, and returning the first element of each, followed by the second, then the third, and so on. So, for example:
{1,1,1}.Interleave( {2,2,2}, {3,3,3} ) => { 1,2,3,1,2,3,1,2,3 }
This operator behaves in a deferred and streaming manner.
When sequences are of unequal length, this method will use the imbalance strategy specified to decide how to continue interleaving the remaining sequences. See for more information.
The sequences are interleaved in the order that they appear in the collection, with as the first sequence.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of the source sequences
member.param: The first sequence in the interleave group
Defines the behavior of the operator when sequences are of unequal length
The other sequences in the interleave group
member.returns: A sequence of interleaved elements from all of the source sequences

member.name: T:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.ImbalancedInterleaveStrategy
member.summary: Defines the strategies available when Interleave is passed sequences of unequal length

member.name: F:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.ImbalancedInterleaveStrategy.Pad
member.summary: Extends a sequence by padding its tail with default(T)

member.name: F:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.ImbalancedInterleaveStrategy.Skip
member.summary: Removes the sequence from the interleave set, and continues interleaving remaining sequences.

member.name: F:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.ImbalancedInterleaveStrategy.Stop
member.summary: Stops the interleave operation.

member.name: T:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.PermutationEnumerator`1
member.summary: The private implementation class that produces permutations of a sequence.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.PermutationEnumerator`1.NextPermutation
member.summary: Transposes elements in the cached permutation array to produce the next permutation

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.PermutationEnumerator`1.PermuteValueSet
member.summary: Creates a new list containing the values from the original set in their new permuted order.
member.remarks: The reason we return a new permuted value set, rather than reuse an existing collection, is that we have no control over what the consumer will do with the results produced. They could very easily generate and store a set of permutations and only then begin to process them. If we reused the same collection, the caller would be surprised to discover that all of the permutations looked the same.
member.returns: List of permuted source sequence values

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Permutations``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Generates a sequence of lists that represent the permutations of the original sequence.
member.remarks:
A permutation is a unique re-ordering of the elements of the sequence.
This operator returns permutations in a deferred, streaming fashion; however, each permutation is materialized into a new list. There are N! permutations of a sequence, where N => sequence.Count().
Be aware that the original sequence is considered one of the permutations and will be returned as one of the results.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the sequence
member.param: The original sequence to permute
member.returns: A sequence of lists representing permutations of the original sequence

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Pipe``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Action{``0})
member.summary: Executes the given action on each element in the source sequence and yields it.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the sequence
member.param: The sequence of elements
The action to execute on each element
member.returns: A sequence with source elements in their original order.
member.remarks: The returned sequence is essentially a duplicate of the original, but with the extra action being executed while the sequence is evaluated. The action is always taken before the element is yielded, so any changes made by the action will be visible in the returned sequence. This operator uses deferred execution and streams it results.

members.member:
Prepends a single value to a sequence.
The type of the elements of . The sequence to prepend to. The value to prepend.
Returns a sequence where a value is prepended to it.
This operator uses deferred execution and streams its results.
int[] numbers = { 1, 2, 3 }; var result = numbers.Prepend(0);
The result variable, when iterated over, will yield 0, 1, 2 and 3, in turn.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.PreScan``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,``0,``0},``0)
member.summary: Performs a pre-scan (exclusive prefix sum) on a sequence of elements.
member.remarks: An exclusive prefix sum returns an equal-length sequence where the N-th element is the sum of the first N-1 input elements (the first element is a special case, it is set to the identity). More generally, the pre-scan allows any commutative binary operation, not just a sum. The inclusive version of PreScan is . This operator uses deferred execution and streams its result.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in source sequence
member.param: Source sequence
Transformation operation
Identity element (see remarks)
member.returns: The scanned sequence

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Random
member.summary: Returns an infinite sequence of random integers using the standard .NET random number generator.
member.returns: An infinite sequence of random integers
member.remarks: The implementation internally uses a shared, thread-local instance of to generate a random number on each iteration. The actual instance used therefore will depend on the thread on which a single iteration is taking place; that is the call to . If the overall iteration takes place on different threads (e.g. via asynchronous awaits completing on different threads) then various different instances will be involved in the generation of the sequence of random numbers. Because the instance is shared, if multiple sequences are generated on the same thread, the order of enumeration affects the resulting sequences.

member.remarks: This operator uses deferred execution and streams its result.
member.example:
var result = Enumerable.Range(1, 5).Scan(0, (a, b) => a + b);
When iterated, result will yield { 0, 1, 3, 6, 10, 15 }.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.ScanRight``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,``0,``0})
member.summary: Peforms a right-associative scan (inclusive prefix) on a sequence of elements. This operator is the right-associative version of the LINQ operator.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in source sequence.
member.param: Source sequence.
A right-associative accumulator function to be invoked on each element. Its first argument is the current value in the sequence; second argument is the previous accumulator value.
member.returns: The scanned sequence.
member.example:
var result = Enumerable.Range(1, 5).Select(i => i.ToString()).ScanRight((a, b) => string.Format("({0}/{1})", a, b));
The result variable will contain [ "(1+(2+(3+(4+5))))", "(2+(3+(4+5)))", "(3+(4+5))", "(4+5)", "5" ].
member.remarks: This operator uses deferred execution and streams its results. Source sequence is consumed greedily when an iteration of the resulting sequence begins.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.SkipUntil``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Skips items from the input sequence until the given predicate returns true when applied to the current source item; that item will be the last skipped.

remarks.para: SkipUntil differs from Enumerable.SkipWhile in two respects. Firstly, the sense of the predicate is reversed: it is expected that the predicate will return false to start with, and then return true - for example, when trying to find a matching item in a sequence.
Secondly, SkipUntil skips the element which causes the predicate to return true. For example, in a sequence { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 } and with a predicate of x => x == 3, the result would be { 4, 5 }.

SkipUntil is as lazy as possible: it will not iterate over the source sequence until it has to, it won't iterate further than it has to, and it won't evaluate the predicate until it has to. (This means that an item may be returned which would actually cause the predicate to throw an exception if it were evaluated, so long as it comes after the first item causing the predicate to return true.)

member.typeparam: Type of the source sequence
member.param: Source sequence
Predicate used to determine when to stop yielding results from the source.
member.returns: Items from the source sequence after the predicate first returns true when applied to the item.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Slice``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Extracts a contiguous count of elements from a sequence at a particular zero-based starting index
member.remarks:
If the starting position or count specified result in slice extending past the end of the sequence, it will return all elements up to that point. There is no guarantee that the resulting sequence will contain the number of elements requested - it may have anywhere from 0 to .
This method is implemented in an optimized manner for any sequence implementing IList{T}.
The result of Slice() is identical to: sequence.Skip(startIndex).Take(count)
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the source sequence
member.param: The sequence from which to extract elements
The zero-based index at which to begin slicing
The number of items to slice out of the index
member.returns: A new sequence containing any elements sliced out from the source sequence

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.Subsets``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Returns a sequence of representing all of the subsets of any size that are part of the original sequence. In mathematics, it is equivalent to the power set of a set.
member.remarks:
This operator produces all of the subsets of a given sequence. Subsets are returned in increasing cardinality, starting with the empty set and terminating with the entire original sequence.
Subsets are produced in a deferred, streaming manner; however, each subset is returned as a materialized list.
There are 2^N subsets of a given sequence, where N => sequence.Count().
member.param: Sequence for which to produce subsets
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the sequence
member.returns: A sequence of lists that represent the all subsets of the original sequence

member.param: Sequence for which to produce subsets
The size of the subsets to produce
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the sequence
member.returns: A sequence of lists that represents of K-sized subsets of the original sequence
member.exception: Thrown if is less than zero.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.MoreEnumerable.TakeUntil``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Returns items from the input sequence until the given predicate returns true when applied to the current source item; that item will be the last returned.

remarks.para: TakeUntil differs from Enumerable.TakeWhile in two respects. Firstly, the sense of the predicate is reversed: it is expected that the predicate will return false to start with, and then return true - for example, when trying to find a matching item in a sequence.
Secondly, TakeUntil yields the element which causes the predicate to return true. For example, in a sequence { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 } and with a predicate of x => x == 3, the result would be { 1, 2, 3 }.

TakeUntil is as lazy as possible: it will not iterate over the source sequence until it has to, it won't iterate further than it has to, and it won't evaluate the predicate until it has to. (This means that an item may be returned which would actually cause the predicate to throw an exception if it were evaluated, so long as no more items of data are requested.)

member.typeparam: Type of the source sequence
member.param: Source sequence
Predicate used to determine when to stop yielding results from the source.

member.summary: Creates an array from an where a function is used to determine the index at which an element will be placed in the array.
member.param: The source sequence for the array.
A function that maps an element to its index.
member.typeparam: The type of the element in .
member.returns: An array that contains the elements from the input sequence. The size of the array will be as large as the highest index returned by the plus 1.
member.remarks: This method forces immediate query evaluation. It should not be used on infinite sequences. If more than one element maps to the same index then the latter element overwrites the former in the resulting array.

member.summary: Transposes a sequence of rows into a sequence of columns.
member.typeparam: Type of source sequence elements.
member.param: Source sequence to transpose.
member.returns: Returns a sequence of columns in the source swapped into rows.
member.remarks: If a rows is shorter than a follow it then the shorter row's elements are skipped in the corresponding column sequences. This operator uses deferred execution and streams its results. Source sequence is consumed greedily when an iteration begins. The inner sequences representing rows are consumed lazily and resulting sequences of columns are streamed.

member.returns: A sequence containing the traversed values.

remarks.para: The tree is not checked for loops. If the resulting sequence needs to be finite then it is the responsibility of to ensure that loops are not produced.

summary.para: Provides a set of static methods for querying objects that implement .

para.strong: THE METHODS ARE EXPERIMENTAL. THEY MAY BE UNSTABLE AND UNTESTED. THEY MAY BE REMOVED FROM A FUTURE MAJOR OR MINOR RELEASE AND POSSIBLY WITHOUT NOTICE. USE THEM AT YOUR OWN RISK. THE METHODS ARE PUBLISHED FOR FIELD EXPERIMENTATION TO SOLICIT FEEDBACK ON THEIR UTILITY AND DESIGN/IMPLEMENTATION DEFECTS.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Experimental.ExperimentalEnumerable.Await``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Threading.Tasks.Task{``0}})
member.summary: Creates a sequence query that streams the result of each task in the source sequence as it completes asynchronously.
member.typeparam: The type of each task's result as well as the type of the elements of the resulting sequence.
member.param: The source sequence of tasks.
member.returns: A sequence query that streams the result of each task in as it completes asynchronously.

remarks.para: This method uses deferred execution semantics. The results are yielded as each asynchronous task completes and, by default, not guaranteed to be based on the source sequence order. If order is important, compose further with .
This method starts a new task where the tasks are awaited. If the resulting sequence is partially consumed then there's a good chance that some tasks will be wasted, those that are in flight.

The tasks in are already assumed to be in flight therefore changing concurrency options via , or will only change how many tasks are awaited at any given moment, not how many will be kept in flight. For the latter effect, use the other overload.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Experimental.ExperimentalEnumerable.Await``2(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Threading.Tasks.Task{``1}})
member.summary: Creates a sequence query that streams the result of each task in the source sequence as it completes asynchronously. A is passed for each asynchronous evaluation to abort any asynchronous operations in flight if the sequence is not fully iterated.
member.typeparam: The type of the source elements.
The type of the result elements.
member.param: The source sequence.
A function to begin the asynchronous evaluation of each element, the second parameter of which is a that can be used to abort asynchronous operations.
member.returns: A sequence query that stream its results as they are evaluated asynchronously.

remarks.para: This method uses deferred execution semantics. The results are yielded as each asynchronous evaluation completes and, by default, not guaranteed to be based on the source sequence order. If order is important, compose further with .

This method starts a new task where the asynchronous evaluations take place and awaited. If the resulting sequence is partially consumed then there's a good chance that some projection work will be wasted and a cooperative effort is done that depends on the function (via a as its second argument) to cancel those in flight.
The function should be designed to be thread-agnostic.

The task returned by should be started when the function is called (and not just a mere projection) otherwise changing concurrency options via , or will only change how many tasks are awaited at any given moment, not how many will be kept in flight.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Experimental.ExperimentalEnumerable.AwaitCompletion``3(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Threading.Tasks.Task{``1}},System.Func{``0,System.Threading.Tasks.Task{``1},``2})
member.summary: Awaits completion of all asynchronous evaluations irrespective of whether they succeed or fail. An additional argument specifies a function that projects the final result given the source item and completed task.

The type of the tasks's result.
The type of the result elements.
member.param: The source sequence.
A function to begin the asynchronous evaluation of each element, the second parameter of which is a that can be used to abort asynchronous operations.
A fucntion that projects the final result given the source item and its asynchronous completion result.
member.returns: A sequence query that stream its results as they are evaluated asynchronously.

remarks.para: This method uses deferred execution semantics. The results are yielded as each asynchronous evaluation completes and, by default, not guaranteed to be based on the source sequence order. If order is important, compose further with .

This method starts a new task where the asynchronous evaluations take place and awaited. If the resulting sequence is partially consumed then there's a good chance that some projection work will be wasted and a cooperative effort is done that depends on the function (via a as its second argument) to cancel those in flight.
The function should be designed to be thread-agnostic.

The task returned by should be started when the function is called (and not just a mere projection) otherwise changing concurrency options via , or will only change how many tasks are awaited at any given moment, not how many will be kept in flight.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Experimental.ExperimentalEnumerable.Memoize``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Creates a sequence that lazily caches the source as it is iterated for the first time, reusing the cache thereafter for future re-iterations. If the source is already cached or buffered then it is returned verbatim.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in .
member.param: The source sequence.
member.returns: Returns a sequence that corresponds to a cached version of the input sequence.
member.remarks: The returned will cache items from in a thread-safe manner. Each thread can call its to acquire an iterator but the same iterator should not be used simultanesouly from multiple threads. The sequence supplied in is not expected to be thread-safe but it is required to be thread-agnostic because different threads (though never simultaneously) may iterate over the sequence.

member.summary: Applies a right-associative accumulator function over a sequence. This operator is the right-associative version of the LINQ operator.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of source.
member.param: Source sequence.
A right-associative accumulator function to be invoked on each element.
member.returns: The final accumulator value.
member.example:
string result = Enumerable.Range(1, 5).Select(i => i.ToString()).AggregateRight((a, b) => string.Format("({0}/{1})", a, b));
The result variable will contain "(1/(2/(3/(4/5))))".
member.remarks: This operator executes immediately.

members.member:
Returns a sequence with each missing element in the source replaced with the following non-missing element in that sequence. Additional parameters specifiy two functions, one used to determine if an element is considered missing or not and another to provide the replacement for the missing element.
The source sequence. The function used to determine if an element in the sequence is considered missing. The function used to produce the element that will replace the missing one. Its first argument receives the current element considered missing while the second argument receives the next non-missing element. Type of the elements in the source sequence. An with missing values replaced.
An with missing elements filled.
This method uses deferred execution semantics and streams its results. If elements are missing at the end of the sequence then they remain missing.

member.name: T:MoreLinq.Extensions.InterleaveExtension
member.summary: Interleave extension.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.InterleaveExtension.Interleave``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0}[])
member.summary: Interleaves the elements of two or more sequences into a single sequence, skipping sequences as they are consumed
member.remarks:
Interleave combines sequences by visiting each in turn, and returning the first element of each, followed by the second, then the third, and so on. So, for example:
{1,1,1}.Interleave( {2,2,2}, {3,3,3} ) => { 1,2,3,1,2,3,1,2,3 }
This operator behaves in a deferred and streaming manner.
When sequences are of unequal length, this method will skip those sequences that have been fully consumed and continue interleaving the remaining sequences.
The sequences are interleaved in the order that they appear in the collection, with as the first sequence.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of the source sequences
member.param: The first sequence in the interleave group
The other sequences in the interleave group
member.returns: A sequence of interleaved elements from all of the source sequences

member.name: T:MoreLinq.Extensions.PermutationsExtension
member.summary: Permutations extension.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.PermutationsExtension.Permutations``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Generates a sequence of lists that represent the permutations of the original sequence.
member.remarks:
A permutation is a unique re-ordering of the elements of the sequence.
This operator returns permutations in a deferred, streaming fashion; however, each permutation is materialized into a new list. There are N! permutations of a sequence, where N => sequence.Count().
Be aware that the original sequence is considered one of the permutations and will be returned as one of the results.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the sequence
member.param: The original sequence to permute
member.returns: A sequence of lists representing permutations of the original sequence

member.returns: A sequence with source elements in their original order.
member.remarks: The returned sequence is essentially a duplicate of the original, but with the extra action being executed while the sequence is evaluated. The action is always taken before the element is yielded, so any changes made by the action will be visible in the returned sequence. This operator uses deferred execution and streams it results.

member.summary: Performs a pre-scan (exclusive prefix sum) on a sequence of elements.
member.remarks: An exclusive prefix sum returns an equal-length sequence where the N-th element is the sum of the first N-1 input elements (the first element is a special case, it is set to the identity). More generally, the pre-scan allows any commutative binary operation, not just a sum. The inclusive version of PreScan is . This operator uses deferred execution and streams its result.

member.param: Source sequence
Transformation operation
Identity element (see remarks)
member.returns: The scanned sequence

member.example:
var result = Enumerable.Range(1, 5).Scan(0, (a, b) => a + b);

member.name: T:MoreLinq.Extensions.ScanRightExtension
member.summary: ScanRight extension.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.ScanRightExtension.ScanRight``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,``0,``0})
member.summary: Peforms a right-associative scan (inclusive prefix) on a sequence of elements. This operator is the right-associative version of the LINQ operator.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in source sequence.
member.param: Source sequence.
A right-associative accumulator function to be invoked on each element. Its first argument is the current value in the sequence; second argument is the previous accumulator value.
member.returns: The scanned sequence.
member.example:
var result = Enumerable.Range(1, 5).Select(i => i.ToString()).ScanRight((a, b) => string.Format("({0}/{1})", a, b));
The result variable will contain [ "(1+(2+(3+(4+5))))", "(2+(3+(4+5)))", "(3+(4+5))", "(4+5)", "5" ].
member.remarks: This operator uses deferred execution and streams its results. Source sequence is consumed greedily when an iteration of the resulting sequence begins.

The type of the accumulator value.
member.param: Source sequence.
The initial accumulator value.
A right-associative accumulator function to be invoked on each element.

member.example:
var result = Enumerable.Range(1, 4).ScanRight("5", (a, b) => string.Format("({0}/{1})", a, b));
The result variable will contain [ "(1+(2+(3+(4+5))))", "(2+(3+(4+5)))", "(3+(4+5))", "(4+5)", "5" ].
member.remarks: This operator uses deferred execution and streams its results. Source sequence is consumed greedily when an iteration of the resulting sequence begins.

member.name: T:MoreLinq.Extensions.SkipUntilExtension
member.summary: SkipUntil extension.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.SkipUntilExtension.SkipUntil``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Skips items from the input sequence until the given predicate returns true when applied to the current source item; that item will be the last skipped.

remarks.para: SkipUntil differs from Enumerable.SkipWhile in two respects. Firstly, the sense of the predicate is reversed: it is expected that the predicate will return false to start with, and then return true - for example, when trying to find a matching item in a sequence.
Secondly, SkipUntil skips the element which causes the predicate to return true. For example, in a sequence { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 } and with a predicate of x => x == 3, the result would be { 4, 5 }.

SkipUntil is as lazy as possible: it will not iterate over the source sequence until it has to, it won't iterate further than it has to, and it won't evaluate the predicate until it has to. (This means that an item may be returned which would actually cause the predicate to throw an exception if it were evaluated, so long as it comes after the first item causing the predicate to return true.)

member.typeparam: Type of the source sequence
member.param: Source sequence
Predicate used to determine when to stop yielding results from the source.
member.returns: Items from the source sequence after the predicate first returns true when applied to the item.

member.name: T:MoreLinq.Extensions.SliceExtension
member.summary: Slice extension.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.SliceExtension.Slice``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Extracts a contiguous count of elements from a sequence at a particular zero-based starting index
member.remarks:
If the starting position or count specified result in slice extending past the end of the sequence, it will return all elements up to that point. There is no guarantee that the resulting sequence will contain the number of elements requested - it may have anywhere from 0 to .
This method is implemented in an optimized manner for any sequence implementing IList{T}.
The result of Slice() is identical to: sequence.Skip(startIndex).Take(count)
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the source sequence
member.param: The sequence from which to extract elements
The zero-based index at which to begin slicing
The number of items to slice out of the index
member.returns: A new sequence containing any elements sliced out from the source sequence

member.name: T:MoreLinq.Extensions.SubsetsExtension
member.summary: Subsets extension.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.SubsetsExtension.Subsets``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Returns a sequence of representing all of the subsets of any size that are part of the original sequence. In mathematics, it is equivalent to the power set of a set.
member.remarks:
This operator produces all of the subsets of a given sequence. Subsets are returned in increasing cardinality, starting with the empty set and terminating with the entire original sequence.
Subsets are produced in a deferred, streaming manner; however, each subset is returned as a materialized list.
There are 2^N subsets of a given sequence, where N => sequence.Count().
member.param: Sequence for which to produce subsets
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the sequence
member.returns: A sequence of lists that represent the all subsets of the original sequence

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.SubsetsExtension.Subsets``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a sequence of representing all subsets of a given size that are part of the original sequence. In mathematics, it is equivalent to the combinations or k-subsets of a set.
member.param: Sequence for which to produce subsets
The size of the subsets to produce
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the sequence
member.returns: A sequence of lists that represents of K-sized subsets of the original sequence
member.exception: Thrown if is less than zero.

member.name: T:MoreLinq.Extensions.TakeUntilExtension
member.summary: TakeUntil extension.

member.name: M:MoreLinq.Extensions.TakeUntilExtension.TakeUntil``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Returns items from the input sequence until the given predicate returns true when applied to the current source item; that item will be the last returned.

remarks.para: TakeUntil differs from Enumerable.TakeWhile in two respects. Firstly, the sense of the predicate is reversed: it is expected that the predicate will return false to start with, and then return true - for example, when trying to find a matching item in a sequence.
Secondly, TakeUntil yields the element which causes the predicate to return true. For example, in a sequence { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 } and with a predicate of x => x == 3, the result would be { 1, 2, 3 }.

TakeUntil is as lazy as possible: it will not iterate over the source sequence until it has to, it won't iterate further than it has to, and it won't evaluate the predicate until it has to. (This means that an item may be returned which would actually cause the predicate to throw an exception if it were evaluated, so long as no more items of data are requested.)

member.typeparam: Type of the source sequence
member.param: Source sequence
Predicate used to determine when to stop yielding results from the source.
member.returns: Items from the source sequence, until the predicate returns true when applied to the item.

member.summary: Transposes a sequence of rows into a sequence of columns.
member.typeparam: Type of source sequence elements.
member.param: Source sequence to transpose.
member.returns: Returns a sequence of columns in the source swapped into rows.
member.remarks: If a rows is shorter than a follow it then the shorter row's elements are skipped in the corresponding column sequences. This operator uses deferred execution and streams its results. Source sequence is consumed greedily when an iteration begins. The inner sequences representing rows are consumed lazily and resulting sequences of columns are streamed.
